snippet: There are no checks on a president’s power to wage nuclear war, though history suggests that there may be ways to slow down or derail the process....
abstract: Question of whether Donald Trump is fit to be in control of American nuclear arsenal, issue that Hillary Clinton has raised on campaign trail, has put spotlight on whether there are meaningful checks on presidential power to deploy nuclear weapons; while no one disputes president's ultimate authority, history suggests there are ways to slow down process in which nuclear strike decision is made.

byline.original: By WILLIAM J. BROAD and DAVID E. SANGER

lead_paragraph: There are no checks on a president’s power to wage nuclear war, though history suggests that there may be ways to slow down or derail the process.

headline.main: Debate Over Trump’s Fitness Raises Issue of Checks on Nuclear Power
headline.print_headline: Issue in Race: Can President Be Kept From Hitting Button?
